schema.name: occurrence-assertion
schema.title: OccurrenceAssertion
schema.description: An Assertion made by an Agent about a dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: assertionID
fields.title: Assertion ID
fields.description: An identifier for an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.title: Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make a dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.

fields.name: verbatimAssertionType
fields.title: Verbatim Assertion Type
fields.description: A string representing the type of Assertion as it appeared in the original record.
fields.comments: This term is meant to allow the capture of an unaltered original name for an Assertion type. This term is meant to be used in addition to dwc:assertionType, not instead of it.

fields.name: assertionType
fields.title: Assertion Type
fields.description: A category that best matches the nature of an Assertion.
fields.examples: `mass`; `mean mass`; `weight standard deviation`; `minimum organism quantity`; `Temperature of the water body`; `salinity`; `Mesh size of sample collector`

fields.name: assertionTypeIRI
fields.title: Assertion Type IRI
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for a type of Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionTypeVocabulary
fields.title: Assertion Type Vocabulary
fields.description: A reference to the controlled vocabulary in which the definition of a value in assertionType is given.

fields.name: assertionMadeDate
fields.title: Assertion Made Date
fields.description: A date on which an Assertion was created.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionEffectiveDate
fields.title: Assertion Effective Date
fields.description: A date on which a state or measurement of an Assertion was deemed to first be in effect.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: assertionValue
fields.title: Assertion Value
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is not numeric.

fields.name: assertionValueIRI
fields.title: Assertion Value IRI
fields.description: An IRI of the controlled vocabulary value for a value of an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionValueVocabulary
fields.title: Assertion Value Vocabulary
fields.description: A reference to a controlled vocabulary in which the definition of a value in assertionValue is given.

fields.name: assertionValueNumeric
fields.title: Assertion Value Numeric
fields.description: An asserted value, if it is numeric.

fields.name: assertionUnit
fields.title: Assertion Unit
fields.description: Units associated with the value in assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI. For units that are composed of multiple parts, use the patterns as given in "A Primer for Communicating Mathematics via Plain Text" (https://cse.sc.edu/~fenner/latex-ASCII.pdf) by Stephen Fenner (e.g., `g/cm^3` for grams per cubic centimeter). For other units, provide the value as a recognizable standard (e.g., '%') or written out in full and in the plural (e.g., `individuals`). It is fine to provide non-SI units in the original language of the dataset.

fields.name: assertionUnitIRI
fields.title: Assertion Unit IRI
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for the units of an assertionValueNumeric.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an IRI for a term in a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: assertionUnitVocabulary
fields.title: Assertion Unit Vocabulary
fields.description: A reference to a controlled vocabulary in which the definition of the value in assertionUnit is given.

fields.name: assertionBy
fields.title: Assertion By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of Agents responsible for making an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`; `bdqtestrunner`

fields.name: assertionByID
fields.title: Assertion By ID
fields.description: An identifier for an Agent responsible for making an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.examples: `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097` (for an individual); `https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 | https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0098` (for a list of people)

fields.name: assertionProtocols
fields.title: Assertion Protocols
fields.description: Names of, references to, or descriptions of Protocols used in making an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionProtocolID
fields.title: Assertion Protocol ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol used to make an Assertion.

fields.name: assertionReferences
fields.title: Assertion References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with an Assertion.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: assertionRemarks
fields.title: Assertion Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about an Assertion.

schema.name: event
schema.title: Event
schema.description: An action, process, or set of circumstances occurring at a dcterms:Location during a period of time.

fields.name: eventID
fields.title: Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: parentEventID
fields.title: Parent Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a broader dwc:Event that groups this and potentially other dwc:Events.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: preferredEventName
fields.title: Preferred Event Name
fields.description: The name of a dwc:Event preferred in searches and results.

fields.name: eventCategory
fields.title: Event Category
fields.description: A broad category that best matches the nature of a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a limited, tightly controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: eventType
fields.title: Event Type
fields.description: A narrow category that best matches the nature of a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: datasetName
fields.title: Dataset Name
fields.description: A name of a dataset from which data originated.

fields.name: datasetID
fields.title: Dataset ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dataset from which data originated.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: fieldNumber
fields.title: Field Number
fields.description: An identifier given to a dwc:Event in the field.
fields.comments: Often serves as a link between field notes and a dwc:Event.

fields.name: eventConductedBy
fields.title: Event Conducted By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of Agents responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`

fields.name: eventConductedByID
fields.title: Event Conducted By ID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent responsible for conducting or recording a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventDate
fields.title: Event Date
fields.description: A date or time interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
fields.comments: For gathering dwc:Events, this is the date-time when the gathering took place.
fields.examples: `1963-03-08T14:07-06:00` (8 Mar 1963 at 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `2009-02-20T08:40Z` (20 February 2009 8:40am UTC); `2018-08-29T15:19` (3:19pm local time on 29 August 2018); `1809-02-12` (some time during 12 February 1809); `1906-06` (some time in June 1906); `1971` (some time in the year 1971); `2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z` (some time during the interval between 1 March 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC); `1900/1909` (some time during the interval between the beginning of the year 1900 and the end of the year 1909); `2007-11-13/15` (some time in the interval between 13 November 2007 and 15 November 2007)

fields.name: eventTime
fields.title: Event Time
fields.description: A time interval during which a dwc:Event occurred.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a time of day that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
fields.examples: `14:07-06:00` (2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC); `08:40:21Z` (8:40:21am UTC); `13:00:00Z/15:30:00Z` (the interval between 1pm UTC and 3:30pm UTC)

fields.name: startDayOfYear
fields.title: Start Day Of Year
fields.description: The earliest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.examples: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

fields.name: endDayOfYear
fields.title: End Day Of Year
fields.description: The latest integer day of the year on which a dwc:Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.examples: `1` (1 January); `32` (1 February); `366` (31 December); `365` (30 December in a leap year, 31 December in a non-leap year)

fields.name: year
fields.title: Year
fields.description: A four-digit year in which a dwc:Event occurred, according to the Common Era Calendar.

fields.name: month
fields.title: Month
fields.description: An integer month in which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: day
fields.title: Day
fields.description: An integer day of the month on which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: verbatimEventDate
fields.title: Verbatim Event Date
fields.description: A verbatim original representation of the date and time information for a dwc:Event.

fields.name: verbatimLocality
fields.title: Verbatim Locality
fields.description: An original textual description of a dcterms:Location.
fields.examples: `25 km NNE Bariloche por R. Nac. 237`

fields.name: verbatimElevation
fields.title: Verbatim Elevation
fields.description: An original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of a dcterms:Location.

fields.name: verbatimDepth
fields.title: Verbatim Depth
fields.description: An original description of the depth below a local surface.

fields.name: verbatimCoordinates
fields.title: Verbatim Coordinates
fields.description: Verbatim original spatial coordinates of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimLatitude
fields.title: Verbatim Latitude
fields.description: A verbatim original latitude of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimLongitude
fields.title: Verbatim Longitude
fields.description: A verbatim original longitude of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.

fields.name: verbatimCoordinateSystem
fields.title: Verbatim Coordinate System
fields.description: A coordinate format for dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude or dwc:verbatimCoordinates.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: verbatimSRS
fields.title: Verbatim SRS
fields.description: An ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which coordinates given in dwc:verbatimLatitude and dwc:verbatimLongitude, or dwc:verbatimCoordinates are based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `not recorded`.

fields.name: georeferenceVerificationStatus
fields.title: Georeference Verification Status
fields.description: A categorical description of the extent to which a georeference has been verified to represent the best possible spatial description for a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.examples: `unable to georeference`; `requires georeference`; `requires verification`; `verified by data custodian`; `verified by contributor`

fields.name: habitat
fields.title: Habitat
fields.description: A category or description of the habitat in which a dwc:Event occurred.

fields.name: eventEffort
fields.title: Event Effort
fields.description: An amount of effort expended during a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `40 trap-nights`; `10 observer-hours`; `10 km by foot`; `30 km by car`

fields.name: fieldNotes
fields.title: Field Notes
fields.description: One of a) an indicator of the existence of, b) a reference to (publication, URI), or c) the text of notes taken in the field about a dwc:Event.

fields.name: eventReferences
fields.title: Event References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261`; `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: eventRemarks
fields.title: Event Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Event.
fields.examples: `After the recent rains the river is nearly at flood stage.`

fields.name: locationID
fields.title: Location ID
fields.description: An identifier a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: higherGeographyID
fields.title: Higher Geography ID
fields.description: An identifier for a geographic region within which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.
fields.examples: `http://vocab.getty.edu/tgn/1002002`  (Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur, Territorio Nacional de la Tierra del Fuego, Argentina).

fields.name: higherGeography
fields.title: Higher Geography
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of geographic names less specific than the information captured in dwc:locality.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `), with terms in order from least specific to most specific.
fields.examples: `North Atlantic Ocean`; `South America | Argentina | Patagonia | Parque Nacional Nahuel Huapi | Neuquén | Los Lagos` with accompanying values `South America` (continent) `Argentina` (country), `Neuquén` (first order division), and `Los Lagos` (second order division)

fields.name: continent
fields.title: Continent
fields.description: A name of a continent in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: waterBody
fields.title: Water Body
fields.description: A name of a water body in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: islandGroup
fields.title: Island Group
fields.description: A name of an island group in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: island
fields.title: Island
fields.description: A name of an island on or near which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

fields.name: country
fields.title: Country
fields.description: A name of a country or major administrative unit in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: countryCode
fields.title: Country Code
fields.description: A standard code for a country in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use an ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 country code, or 'ZZ' (for an unknown location or a location unassignable to a single country code), or 'XZ' (for the high seas beyond national jurisdictions). Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: stateProvince
fields.title: State Province
fields.description: A name of a next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: county
fields.title: County
fields.description: A full, unabbreviated name of a next smaller administrative region than dwc:stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if the dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if the dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term dwc:higherGeography or in the term dwc:locality, or both.

fields.name: municipality
fields.title: Municipality
fields.description: A full, unabbreviated name of a next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which a dcterms:Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Recommended best practice is to leave this field blank if a dcterms:Location spans multiple entities at this administrative level or if a dcterms:Location might be in one or another of multiple possible entities at this level. Multiplicity and uncertainty of the geographic entity can be captured either in the term `higherGeography` or in the term `locality`, or both.

fields.name: locality
fields.title: Locality
fields.description: A specific description of the location of a place.
fields.comments: Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
fields.examples: `Bariloche, 25 km NNE via Ruta Nacional 40 (=Ruta 237)`; `Queets Rainforest, Olympic National Park`

fields.name: minimumElevationInMeters
fields.title: Minimum Elevation In Meters
fields.description: A lower limit of a range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.

fields.name: maximumElevationInMeters
fields.title: Maximum Elevation In Meters
fields.description: An upper limit of a range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.

fields.name: verticalDatum
fields.title: Vertical Datum
fields.description: A vertical datum used as a reference upon which the values in the elevation terms are based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

fields.name: minimumDepthInMeters
fields.title: Minimum Depth In Meters
fields.description: A lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.

fields.name: maximumDepthInMeters
fields.title: Maximum Depth In Meters
fields.description: A greater depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.

fields.name: minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters
fields.title: Minimum Distance Above Surface In Meters
fields.description: A lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
fields.examples: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

fields.name: maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters
fields.title: Maximum Distance Above Surface In Meters
fields.description: A greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
fields.examples: `-1.5` (below the surface); `4.2` (above the surface); For a 1.5 meter sediment core from the bottom of a lake (at depth 20m) at 300m elevation: verbatimElevation: `300m` minimumElevationInMeters: `300`, maximumElevationInMeters: `300`, verbatimDepth: `20m`, minimumDepthInMeters: `20`, maximumDepthInMeters: `20`, minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `0`, maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters: `-1.5`.

fields.name: locationRemarks
fields.title: Location Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dcterms:Location.

fields.name: decimalLatitude
fields.title: Decimal Latitude
fields.description: A geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.

fields.name: decimalLongitude
fields.title: Decimal Longitude
fields.description: A geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in dwc:geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.

fields.name: geodeticDatum
fields.title: Geodetic Datum
fields.description: An ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geographic coordinates given in dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude as based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `not recorded`.

fields.name: coordinateUncertaintyInMeters
fields.title: Coordinate Uncertainty In Meters
fields.description: A horizontal distance (in meters) from a given dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude describing the smallest circle containing the whole of the dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Leave the value empty if the uncertainty is unknown, cannot be estimated, or is not applicable (because there are no coordinates). Zero is not a valid value for this term.
fields.examples: `30` (reasonable lower limit on or after 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `100` (reasonable lower limit before 2000-05-01 of a GPS reading under good conditions if the actual precision was not recorded at the time); `71` (uncertainty for a UTM coordinate having 100 meter precision and a known spatial reference system)

fields.name: coordinatePrecision
fields.title: Coordinate Precision
fields.description: A decimal representation of the precision of the coordinates given in a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude.
fields.examples: `0.00001` (normal GPS limit for decimal degrees); `0.000278` (nearest second); `0.01667` (nearest minute); `1.0` (nearest degree)

fields.name: pointRadiusSpatialFit
fields.title: Point Radius Spatial Fit
fields.description: A ratio of the area of a point-radius (dwc:decimalLatitude, dwc:decimalLongitude, dwc:coordinateUncertaintyInMeters) to the area of a true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given point-radius does not completely contain the original representation. The pointRadiusSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, the pointRadiusSpatialFit is 1. Detailed explanations with graphical examples can be found in the Georeferencing Best Practices, Chapman and Wieczorek, 2020 (https://doi.org/10.15468/doc-gg7h-s853).

fields.name: footprintWKT
fields.title: Footprint WKT
fields.description: A Well-Known Text (WKT) representation of the shape (footprint, geometry) that defines a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: A dcterms:Location may have both a point-radius representation (see dwc:decimalLatitude) and a footprint representation, and they may differ from each other.
fields.examples: `POLYGON ((10 20, 11 20, 11 21, 10 21, 10 20))` (the one-degree bounding box with opposite corners at longitude=10, latitude=20 and longitude=11, latitude=21)

fields.name: footprintSRS
fields.title: Footprint SRS
fields.description: An ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which a geometry given in dwc:footprintWKT is based.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `not recorded`. It is also permitted to provide the SRS in Well-Known-Text, especially if no EPSG code provides the necessary values for the attributes of the SRS. Do not use this term to describe the SRS of a dwc:decimalLatitude and dwc:decimalLongitude, nor of any verbatim coordinates - use dwc:geodeticDatum and dwc:verbatimSRS instead.
fields.examples: `EPSG:4326`; `GEOGCS['GCS_WGS_1984', DATUM['D_WGS_1984', SPHEROID['WGS_1984',6378137,298.257223563]], PRIMEM['Greenwich',0], UNIT['Degree',0.0174532925199433]]` (WKT for the standard WGS84 Spatial Reference System EPSG:4326)

fields.name: footprintSpatialFit
fields.title: Footprint Spatial Fit
fields.description: A ratio of the area of a footprint (dwc:footprintWKT) to the area of a true (original, or most specific) spatial representation of a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given footprint does not completely contain the original representation. A dwc:footprintSpatialFit is undefined (and should be left empty) if the original representation is any geometry without area (e.g., a point or polyline) and without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same geometry (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, a dwc:footprintSpatialFit is 1.

fields.name: georeferencedBy
fields.title: Georeferenced By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of Agents responsible for determining a georeference (spatial representation) for a dcterms:Location.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

fields.name: georeferencedByID
fields.title: Georeferenced By ID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent responsible for determining a georeference for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: georeferencedDate
fields.title: Georeferenced Date
fields.description: A date on which a dcterms:Location was georeferenced.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: georeferenceProtocol
fields.title: Georeference Protocol
fields.description: A description or reference to a Protocol used to determine the spatial footprint, coordinates, and uncertainties.
fields.examples: `Georeferencing Quick Reference Guide (Zermoglio et al. 2020, https://doi.org/10.35035/e09p-h128)`

fields.name: georeferenceProtocolID
fields.title: Georeference Protocol ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Protocol used to georeference a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: georeferenceSources
fields.title: Georeference Sources
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of maps, gazetteers, or other resources used to georeference a dcterms:Location, described specifically enough to allow anyone in the future to use the same resources.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `https://www.geonames.org/`; `USGS 1:24000 Florence Montana Quad 1967 | Terrametrics 2008 on Google Earth`; `GeoLocate`

fields.name: georeferenceRemarks
fields.title: Georeference Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a spatial description determination, explaining assumptions made in addition or opposition to the those formalized in the method referred to in dwc:georeferenceProtocol.

fields.name: informationWithheld
fields.title: Information Withheld
fields.description: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
fields.examples: `location information not given for endangered species`; `collector identities withheld | ask about tissue samples`

fields.name: dataGeneralizations
fields.title: Data Generalizations
fields.description: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
fields.examples: `coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell`

fields.name: preferredSpatialRepresentation
fields.title: Preferred Spatial Representation
fields.description: An indication of which spatial representation best represents the dcterms:Location.

fields.name: projectID
fields.title: Project ID
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers for projects that contributed to a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: A projectID can be may be shared in multiple distinct datasets. The nature of the association can be described in the metadata project description element. This term should be used to provide a globally unique identifier (GUID) for a project, if available. This could be a DOI, URI, or any other persistent identifier that ensures a project can be uniquely distinguished from others. The recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: projectTitle
fields.title: Project Title
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of titles or names for projects that contributed to a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Use this term to provide the official name or title of a project as it is commonly known and cited. Avoid abbreviations unless they are widely understood. The recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: fundingAttribution
fields.title: Funding Attribution
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of the funding organizations or agencies that provided funding for the project.
fields.comments: Specify the full official name of the funding body. This should include the complete name without abbreviations, unless the abbreviation is an official and commonly recognized form (e.g., NSF for the National Science Foundation). The recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: fundingAttributionID
fields.title: Funding Attribution ID
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of the globally unique identifiers for the funding organizations or agencies that supported the project.
fields.comments: Provide a unique identifier for the funding body, such as an identifier used in governmental or international databases. If no official identifier exists, use a persistent and unique identifier within your organization or dataset. The recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: feedbackURL
fields.title: Feedback URL
fields.comments: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.

schema.name: event-media
schema.title: EventMedia
schema.description: A link establishing a dwc:Event as content of a Media entity.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventID
fields.title: Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategory
fields.title: Media Subject Category
fields.description: A term to describe the content of the image by a value from a controlled vocabulary.
fields.comments: Controlled vocabulary of subjects to support broad classification of media items. Terms from various controlled vocabularies may be used. AC-recommended vocabularies are preferred and MAY be unqualified literals (not a full URI). For terms from other vocabularies either a precise URI SHOULD be used, or, as long as all unqualified terms in all vocabularies are unique, metadata SHOULD provide the source vocabularies using the Subject Category Vocabulary term. The value SHOULD be a string, whose text can also be in the form of a URL. These guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified by the IPTC guidelines.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryIRI
fields.title: Media Subject Category IRI
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of a Media instance.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryVocabulary
fields.title: Media Subject Category Vocabulary
fields.description: Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.
fields.comments: The AC recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.

fields.name: subjectPart
fields.title: SubjectPart
fields.description: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the media resource.

fields.name: subjectOrientation
fields.title: SubjectOrientation
fields.description: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the media resource with respect to the acquisition device.

fields.name: physicalSetting
fields.title: PhysicalSetting
fields.description: The setting of the content represented in media such as images, sounds, and movies if the provider deems them relevant. Constrained vocabulary of: `Natural` = Object in its natural setting of the object (e. g. living organisms in their natural environment); `Artificial` = Object in an artificial environment (e. g. living organisms in an artificial environment such as a zoo, garden, greenhouse, or laboratory); `Edited` = Human media editing of a natural setting or media acquisition with a separate media background such as a photographic backdrop.

schema.name: occurrence
schema.title: Occurrence
schema.description: A state of a dwc:Organism in a dwc:Event.

fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.title: Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier. In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make a dwc:occurrenceID globally unique.

fields.name: eventID
fields.title: Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: surveyTargetID
fields.title: Survey Target ID
fields.description: An identifier for a SurveyTarget.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: recordedBy
fields.title: Recorded By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of Agents responsible for recording a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).
fields.examples: `José E. Crespo`; `Oliver P. Pearson | Anita K. Pearson`; `FMNH`

fields.name: recordedByID
fields.title: Recorded By ID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent responsible for recording a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: organismQuantity
fields.title: Organism Quantity
fields.description: A number or enumeration value for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.
fields.comments: A dwc:organismQuantity must have a corresponding dwc:organismQuantityType.
fields.examples: `27` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType); `12.5` (organismQuantity) with `% biomass` (organismQuantityType); `r` (organismQuantity) with `Braun-Blanquet Scale` (organismQuantityType); `many` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType)

fields.name: organismQuantityType
fields.title: Organism Quantity Type
fields.description: A type of quantification system used for the quantity of dwc:Organisms.
fields.comments: A dwc:organismQuantityType must have a corresponding dwc:organismQuantity. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.
fields.examples: `27` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType); `12.5` (organismQuantity) with `% biomass` (organismQuantityType); `r` (organismQuantity) with `Braun-Blanquet Scale` (organismQuantityType); `many` (organismQuantity) with `individuals` (organismQuantityType)

fields.name: sex
fields.title: Sex
fields.description: A sex of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: lifeStage
fields.title: Life Stage
fields.description: An age class or life stage of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: reproductiveCondition
fields.title: Reproductive Condition
fields.description: A reproductive condition of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: caste
fields.title: Caste
fields.description: A social caste of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary that aligns best with a dwc:Taxon. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: behavior
fields.title: Behavior
fields.description: A behavior shown by a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: vitality
fields.title: Vitality
fields.description: An indication of whether a dwc:Organism was alive or dead at the time of collection or observation.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. Intended to be used with records having a dwc:basisOfRecord of 'PreservedSpecimen', 'MaterialEntity', 'MaterialSample', 'HumanObservation', or 'MachineObservation'. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: establishmentMeans
fields.title: Establishment Means
fields.description: Statement about whether a dwc:Organism has been introduced to a given place and time through the direct or indirect activity of modern humans.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/em/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: degreeOfEstablishment
fields.title: Degree Of Establishment
fields.description: The degree to which a dwc:Organism survives, reproduces, and expands its range at a given place and time.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/doe/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: pathway
fields.title: Pathway
fields.description: A process by which a dwc:Organism came to be in a given place at a given time.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use controlled value strings from the controlled vocabulary designated for use with this term, listed at http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/pw/. For details, refer to https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: substrate
fields.title: Substrate
fields.description: A biotic or abiotic material to which an dwc:Organism is attached when a dwc:Event occurs.
fields.comments: This may or may not imply that the organism influenced/took resources from the substrate (such as during parasitization or decomposition). Declaration of a host-parasite relationship is better expressed as an organism interaction.

fields.name: occurrenceStatus
fields.title: Occurrence Status
fields.description: A statement about the detection or non-detection of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: For dwc:Occurrences, the default vocabulary is recommended to consist of 'detected' and 'notDetected', but can be extended by implementers with good justification. This term has an equivalent in the dwciri: namespace that allows only an IRI as a value, whereas this term allows for any string literal value.

fields.name: occurrenceReferences
fields.title: Occurrence References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with a dwc:Occurrence.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.`; `Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.`

fields.name: informationWithheld
fields.title: Information Withheld
fields.description: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
fields.examples: `location information not given for endangered species`; `collector identities withheld | ask about tissue samples`

fields.name: dataGeneralizations
fields.title: Data Generalizations
fields.description: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
fields.examples: `coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell`

fields.name: occurrenceRemarks
fields.title: Occurrence Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Occurrence.

fields.name: organismID
fields.title: Organism ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Organism.

fields.name: organismScope
fields.title: Organism Scope
fields.description: A description of the type of dwc:Organism instance.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. Can be used to indicate whether a dwc:Organism instance represents a discrete organism or if it represents a particular type of aggregation.

fields.name: organismName
fields.title: Organism Name
fields.description: A name or label assigned to a dwc:Organism.

fields.name: causeOfDeath
fields.title: Cause Of Death
fields.description: An indication of the known or suspected cause of death of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: The cause may be due to natural causes (e.g., disease, predation), human-related activities (e.g., roadkill, pollution), or other environmental factors (e.g., extreme weather events).

fields.name: organismRemarks
fields.title: Organism Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Organism.

fields.name: verbatimIdentification
fields.title: Verbatim Identification
fields.description: A string representing a taxonomic identification as it appeared in the original record.

fields.name: taxonFormula
fields.title: Taxon Formula
fields.description: A string representing the pattern to use to construct a dwc:Identification from dwc:Taxon names and identification qualifiers.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as https://arctos.database.museum/info/ctDocumentation.cfm?table=cttaxa_formula.
fields.examples: `A`; `A ?`; `A or B`; `A and B`; `A x B`; `A cf.`; `A aff.`

fields.name: identifiedBy
fields.title: Identified By
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of Agents responsible for making a taxonomic determination of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: When used in the context of a Survey, the subject consists of all of the dwc:Identifications related to the Event. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: identifiedByID
fields.title: Identified By ID
fields.description: An identifier for the Agent responsible for making a taxonomic determination of a dwc:Organism.
fields.comments: When used in the context of a Survey, the subject consists of all of the dwc:Identifications related to the Survey. Recommended best practice is to provide a single identifier that disambiguates the details of the identifying agent. If a list is used, the order of the identifiers on the list should not be assumed to convey any semantics. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

fields.name: dateIdentified
fields.title: Date Identified
fields.description: A date on which the subject was determined as representing a dwc:Taxon.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

fields.name: identificationReferences
fields.title: Identification References
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers for References (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI, metabarcoding reference database) used in a dwc:Identification.
fields.comments: When used in the context of a Survey, the subject consists of all of the dwc:Identifications related to the Survey. Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).
fields.examples: `Aves del Noroeste Patagonico. Christie et al. 2004.`; `Stebbins, R. Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. 3rd Edition. 2003. | Irschick, D.J. and Shaffer, H.B. (1997). The polytypic species revisited: Morphological differentiation among tiger salamanders (Ambystoma tigrinum) (Amphibia: Caudata). Herpetologica, 53(1), 30-49.`

fields.name: identificationVerificationStatus
fields.title: Identification Verification Status
fields.description: A categorical indicator of the extent to which a taxonomic determination has been verified to be correct.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as that used in HISPID and ABCD.

fields.name: identificationRemarks
fields.title: Identification Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Identification.
fields.examples: `Distinguished between Anthus correndera and Anthus hellmayri based on the comparative lengths of the uñas.`

fields.name: taxonID
fields.title: Taxon ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Taxon.
fields.comments: In DwC-DP, the taxonID is always an external link to a taxon record. As such, if present, it should be a resolvable globally unique identifier. See the Identifiers section of https://github.com/CatalogueOfLife/coldp/blob/master/README.md.

fields.name: higherClassificationName
fields.title: Higher Classification Name
fields.description: A full scientific name at a higher rank than the taxonRank of a dwc:scientificName.
fields.comments: A higherClassificationName must have a corresponding higherClassificationRank.

fields.name: higherClassificationRank
fields.title: Higher Classification Rank
fields.description: A taxonomic rank of a higherClassificationName.
fields.comments: A higherClassificationRank must have a corresponding higherClassificationName.

fields.name: scientificName
fields.title: Scientific Name
fields.description: A full scientific name, with authorship and date information if known. When forming part of a dwc:Identification, this should be the name in lowest level taxonomic rank that can be determined. This term should not contain identification qualifications, which should instead be supplied in dwc:verbatimIdentification.

fields.name: taxonRank
fields.title: Taxon Rank
fields.description: A taxonomic rank of the most specific name in a dwc:scientificName.

fields.name: taxonRemarks
fields.title: Taxon Remarks
fields.description: Comments or notes about a dwc:Taxon.
fields.examples: `this name is a misspelling in common use`

fields.name: feedbackURL
fields.title: Feedback URL
fields.comments: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.

schema.name: organism-interaction-media
schema.title: OrganismInteractionMedia
schema.description: A link establishing an OrganismInteraction as content of a Media entity.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: organismInteractionID
fields.title: Organism Interaction ID
fields.description: An identifier for an OrganismInteraction.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategory
fields.title: Media Subject Category
fields.description: A term to describe the content of the image by a value from a controlled vocabulary.
fields.comments: Controlled vocabulary of subjects to support broad classification of media items. Terms from various controlled vocabularies may be used. AC-recommended vocabularies are preferred and MAY be unqualified literals (not a full URI). For terms from other vocabularies either a precise URI SHOULD be used, or, as long as all unqualified terms in all vocabularies are unique, metadata SHOULD provide the source vocabularies using the Subject Category Vocabulary term. The value SHOULD be a string, whose text can also be in the form of a URL. These guidelines on value format are less restrictive than is specified by the IPTC guidelines.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryIRI
fields.title: Media Subject Category IRI
fields.description: An IRI of a controlled vocabulary value for the subject category of a Media instance.

fields.name: mediaSubjectCategoryVocabulary
fields.title: Media Subject Category Vocabulary
fields.description: Any vocabulary or formal classification from which terms in the Subject Category have been drawn.
fields.comments: The AC recommended vocabularies do not need to be cited here. There is no required linkage between individual Subject Category terms and the vocabulary; the mechanism is intended to support discovery of the normative URI for a term, but not guarantee it.

fields.name: subjectPart
fields.title: SubjectPart
fields.description: The portion or product of organism morphology, behaviour, environment, etc. that is either predominantly shown or particularly well exemplified by the media resource.

fields.name: subjectOrientation
fields.title: SubjectOrientation
fields.description: Specific orientation (= direction, view angle) of the subject represented in the media resource with respect to the acquisition device.

fields.name: physicalSetting
fields.title: PhysicalSetting
fields.description: The setting of the content represented in media such as images, sounds, and movies if the provider deems them relevant. Constrained vocabulary of: `Natural` = Object in its natural setting of the object (e. g. living organisms in their natural environment); `Artificial` = Object in an artificial environment (e. g. living organisms in an artificial environment such as a zoo, garden, greenhouse, or laboratory); `Edited` = Human media editing of a natural setting or media acquisition with a separate media background such as a photographic backdrop.

schema.name: organism-interaction
schema.title: OrganismInteraction
schema.description: An interaction between two dwc:Organisms during a dwc:Event.

fields.name: organismInteractionID
fields.title: Organism Interaction ID
fields.description: An identifier for an OrganismInteraction.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: eventID
fields.title: Event ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Event.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: organismInteractionDescription
fields.title: Organism Interaction Description
fields.description: A verbatim description of an OrganismInteraction.
fields.examples: `Mallophora ruficauda capturing an Apis mellifera worker in flight.`

fields.name: subjectOccurrenceID
fields.title: Subject Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a subject dwc:Occurrence in an OrganismInteraction.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: subjectOrganismPart
fields.title: Subject Organism Part
fields.description: A part of a subject dwc:Organism involved in an OrganismInteraction.

fields.name: organismInteractionType
fields.title: Organism Interaction Type
fields.description: A category that best matches the nature of an OrganismInteraction.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.examples: `visited flower of`; `pollinated by`; `parasitoid of`; `mated with`; `was attached to`

fields.name: relatedOccurrenceID
fields.title: Related Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a related dwc:Occurrence in an OrganismInteraction.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: relatedOrganismPart
fields.title: Related Organism Part
fields.description: A part of a object dwc:Organism involved in an OrganismInteraction.

fields.name: feedbackURL
fields.title: Feedback URL
fields.comments: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.

schema.name: media
schema.title: Media
schema.description: A dcmi:MediaType (dcmi:Sounds, dcmi:StillImages, dcmi:MovingImages or dcmi:Text) with other entities as content.

fields.name: mediaID
fields.title: Media ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Media instance.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: mediaType
fields.title: Media Type
fields.description: A category that best matches the nature of an instance of Media.

fields.name: subtypeLiteral
fields.title: SubtypeLiteral
fields.description: The subtype should provide more specialization than the type. Possible values are community-defined. For examples see the non-normative page AC_Subtype_Examples.

fields.name: subtype
fields.title: Subtype
fields.description: Any URI may be used that provides for more specialization than the type. Possible values are community-defined. For exmamples see the non-normative page AC_Subtype_Examples.

fields.name: title
fields.title: Title
fields.description: Concise title, name, or brief descriptive label of institution, resource collection, or individual resource. This field should include the complete title with all the subtitles, if any.

fields.name: modified
fields.title: Modified
fields.description: Date that the media resource was altered. The date and time must comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004. AC datetime values may also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus (`forward slash`; '/'). See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry for further explanation and examples.

fields.name: MetadataDate
fields.title: MetadataDate
fields.description: Point in time recording when the last modification to metadata (not necessarily the media object itself) occurred. The date and time must comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004. AC datetime values may also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus (`forward slash`; '/'). See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry for further explanation and examples.

fields.name: metadataLanguageLiteral
fields.title: MetadataLanguageLiteral
fields.description: Language of description and other metadata (but not necessarily of the image itself) represented as an ISO639-2 three letter language code. ISO639-1 two-letter codes are permitted but deprecated. Note: At least one of ac:metadataLanguage and ac:metadataLanguageLiteral must be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both may make the metadata more widely useful.

fields.name: metadataLanguage
fields.title: MetadataLanguage
fields.description: URI from the ISO639-2 list of URIs for ISO 3-letter language codes. Note: At least one of ac:metadataLanguage and ac:metadataLanguageLiteral must be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both may make the metadata more widely useful

fields.name: commenterLiteral
fields.title: CommenterLiteral
fields.description: A name or the literal `anonymous` (= anonymously commented).

fields.name: commenter
fields.title: Commenter
fields.description: A URI denoting a person, using some controlled vocabulary such as FOAF. Implementers and communities of practice may produce restrictions or recommendations on the choice of vocabularies. See also the entry for ac:commenterLiteral in this document and the section Namespaces, Prefixes and Term Names for discussion of the rationale for separate terms taking URI values from those taking Literal values where both are possible. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.

fields.name: comments
fields.title: Comments
fields.description: Any comment provided on the media resource, as free-form text. Best practice would also identify the commenter.

fields.name: reviewerLiteral
fields.title: ReviewerLiteral
fields.description: String providing the name of a reviewer. If present, then resource is peer-reviewed, even if Reviewer Comments is absent or empty. Its presence tells whether an expert in the subject featured in the media has reviewed the media item or collection and approved its metadata description; must display a name or the literal `anonymous` (= anonymously reviewed).

fields.name: reviewer
fields.title: Reviewer
fields.description: URI for a reviewer. If present, then resource is peer-reviewed, even if there are Reviewer Comments is absent or empty. Its presence tells whether an expert in the subject featured in the media has reviewed the media item or collection and approved its metadata description; must display a name or the literal `anonymous` (= anonymously reviewed).

fields.name: reviewerComments
fields.title: ReviewerComments
fields.description: Any comment provided by a reviewer with expertise in the subject, as free-form text.

fields.name: available
fields.title: Available
fields.description: The date (often a range) that the resource became or will become available. The date and time must comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004. AC datetime values may also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus (`forward slash`; '/'). See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry for further explanation and examples.

fields.name: hasServiceAccessPoint
fields.title: HasServiceAccessPoint
fields.description: In a chosen serialization (RDF, XML Schema, etc.) the potentially multiple service access points (e.g., for different resolutions of an image) might be provided in a referenced or in a nested object. This property identifies one such access point. That is, each of potentially multiple values of hasServiceAccessPoint identifies a set of representation-dependent metadata using the properties defined under the section Service Access Point Vocabulary.

fields.name: rights
fields.title: Rights
fields.description: Information about rights held in and over the resource. A full-text, readable copyright statement, as required by the national legislation of the copyright holder. On collections, this applies to all contained objects, unless the object itself has a different statement. Examples: “Copyright XY 2008, all rights reserved”, “© 2008 XY Museum” , `Public Domain.`; `Copyright unknown.` Do not place just the name of the copyright holder(s) here! That belongs in a list in the xmpRights:Owner field, which should be supplied if dc:rights is not 'Public Domain', which is appropriate only if the resource is known to be not under copyright. See also the entry for dcterms:rights in this document and see the DCMI FAQ on DC and DCTERMS Namespaces for discussion of the rationale for terms in two namespaces. Normal practice is to use the same Label if both are provided. Labels have no effect on information discovery and are only suggestions.
fields.examples: `Copyright 2014 Ron Thomas` or a URI like `http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode`

fields.name: rightsIRI
fields.title: Rights IRI
fields.description: A URI pointing to structured information about rights held in and over the resource. Examples include http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode and http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/. At least one of dcterms:rights and dc:rights must be supplied but, when feasible, supplying both may make the metadata more widely useful. They must specify the same rights. In case of ambiguity, dcterms:rights prevails.

fields.name: Owner
fields.title: Owner
fields.description: A list of the names of the owners of the copyright. 'Unknown' is an acceptable value, but 'Public Domain' is not.
fields.examples: `The names of the owners `Ron Thomas, Roz Thomas` or a URI that identifies the owner`

fields.name: UsageTerms
fields.title: UsageTerms
fields.description: The license statement defining how resources may be used. Information on a collection applies to all contained objects unless the object has a different statement.

fields.name: WebStatement
fields.title: WebStatement
fields.description: A URL defining or further elaborating on the license statement (e. g., a web page explaining the precise terms of use).

fields.name: licenseLogoURL
fields.title: LicenseLogoURL
fields.description: A URL providing access to a logo that symbolizes the License.

fields.name: Credit
fields.title: Credit
fields.description: free text for `Please cite this as…`

fields.name: attributionLogoURL
fields.title: AttributionLogoURL
fields.description: The URL of the icon or logo image to appear in source attribution.

fields.name: attributionLinkURL
fields.title: AttributionLinkURL
fields.description: The URL where information about ownership, attribution, etc. of the resource may be found.

fields.name: fundingAttribution
fields.title: FundingAttribution
fields.description: Organizations or individuals who funded the creation of the resource.

fields.name: fundingAttributionID
fields.title: Funding Atribution ID
fields.description: A list (concatenated and separated) of the globally unique identifiers for the funding organizations or agencies that supported the project.
fields.comments: Provide a unique identifier for the funding body, such as an identifier used in governmental or international databases. If no official identifier exists, use a persistent and unique identifier within your organization or dataset. The recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space ( | ).

fields.name: source
fields.title: Source
fields.description: A string providing an identifiable source from which the described resources was derived.

fields.name: sourceIRI
fields.title: Source IRI
fields.description: URI for an identifiable source from which the described resources was derived.

fields.name: creator
fields.title: Creator
fields.description: The person or organization responsible for creating the media resource.

fields.name: creatorIRI
fields.title: Creator IRI
fields.description: A URI representing the person or organization responsible for creating the media resource.

fields.name: providerLiteral
fields.title: ProviderLiteral
fields.description: Person or organization responsible for presenting the media resource. If no separate Metadata Provider is given, this also attributes the metadata.

fields.name: provider
fields.title: Provider
fields.description: URI for person or organization responsible for presenting the media resource. If no separate Metadata Provider is given, this also attributes the metadata.

fields.name: metadataCreatorLiteral
fields.title: MetadataCreatorLiteral
fields.description: Person or organization originally creating the resource metadata record.

fields.name: metadataCreator
fields.title: MetadataCreator
fields.description: Person or organization originally creating the resource metadata record.

fields.name: metadataProviderLiteral
fields.title: MetadataProviderLiteral
fields.description: Person or organization originally responsible for providing the resource metadata record.

fields.name: metadataProvider
fields.title: MetadataProvider
fields.description: URI of person or organization originally responsible for providing the resource metadata record.

fields.name: description
fields.title: Description
fields.description: Description of collection or individual resource, containing the Who, What, When, Where and Why as free-form text. This normative document is silent on the nature of formatting in the text. It is the role of implementers of an AC concrete representation (e.g., an XML Schema, an RDF representation, etc.) to decide and document how formatting advice will be represented in descriptions serialized according to such representations.

fields.name: caption
fields.title: Caption
fields.description: As alternative or in addition to description, a caption is free-form text to be displayed together with (rather than instead of) a resource that is suitable for captions (especially images).

fields.name: language
fields.title: Language
fields.description: Language(s) of resource itself represented in the ISO639-2 three-letter language code. ISO639-1 two-letter codes are permitted but deprecated.

fields.name: languageIRI
fields.title: Language IRI
fields.description: URI from the ISO639-2 list of URIs for ISO 3-letter language codes.

fields.name: CreateDate
fields.title: CreateDate
fields.description: The date of the creation of the original resource from which the digital media was derived or created. The date and time must comply with the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) datetime practice, which requires that date and time representation correspond to ISO 8601:1998, but with year fields always comprising 4 digits. This makes datetime records compliant with 8601:2004. AC datetime values may also follow 8601:2004 for ranges by separating two IS0 8601 datetime fields by a solidus (`forward slash`; '/'). See also the wikipedia IS0 8601 entry for further explanation and examples.

fields.name: timeOfDay
fields.title: TimeOfDay
fields.description: Free text information beyond exact clock times.

fields.name: captureDevice
fields.title: CaptureDevice
fields.description: Free form text describing the device or devices used to create the resource.

fields.name: resourceCreationTechnique
fields.title: ResourceCreationTechnique
fields.description: Information about technical aspects of the creation and digitization process of the resource. This includes modification steps (`retouching`) after the initial resource capture.

fields.name: collectionCode
fields.title: Collection Code
fields.description: A name, acronym, coden, or initialism identifying a Collection.

fields.name: collectionID
fields.title: Collection ID
fields.description: An identifier for a Collection.
fields.comments: For physical specimens, the recommended best practice is to use a globally unique and resolvable identifier from a collections registry such as the Global Registry of Scientific Collections (https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/).

fields.name: derivedFrom
fields.title: DerivedFrom
fields.description: A reference to an original resource from which the current one is derived.

fields.name: accessURI
fields.title: AccessURI
fields.description: A URI that uniquely identifies a service that provides a representation of the underlying resource. If this resource can be acquired by an http request, its http URL should be given. If not, but it has some URI in another URI scheme, that may be given here.

fields.name: format
fields.title: Format
fields.description: A string describing the technical format of the resource (file format or physical medium).

fields.name: formatIRI
fields.title: Format
fields.description: URI referencing the technical format of the resource (file format or physical medium).

fields.name: variantLiteral
fields.title: VariantLiteral
fields.description: Text that describes this Service Access Point variant.

fields.name: variant
fields.title: Variant
fields.description: A URI designating what this Service Access Point provides. Some suggested values are the URIs ac:Thumbnail, ac:Trailer, ac:LowerQuality, ac:MediumQuality, ac:GoodQuality, ac:BestQuality, and ac:Offline. Additional URIs from communities of practice may be introduced.

fields.name: variantDescription
fields.title: VariantDescription
fields.description: Text that describes this Service Access Point variant

fields.name: furtherInformationURL
fields.title: FurtherInformationURL
fields.description: The URL of a Web site that provides additional information about the version of the media resource that is provided by the Service Access Point.

fields.name: licensingException
fields.title: LicensingException
fields.description: The licensing statement for this variant of the media resource if different from that given in the License Statement property of the resource.

fields.name: serviceExpectation
fields.title: ServiceExpectation
fields.description: A term that describes what service expectations users may have of the ac:accessURL. Recommended terms include online (denotes that the URL is expected to deliver the resource), authenticate (denotes that the URL delivers a login or other authentication interface requiring completion before delivery of the resource) published(non digital) (denotes that the URL is the identifier of a non-digital published work, for example a doi.) Communities should develop their own controlled vocabularies for Service Expectations.

fields.name: hashFunction
fields.title: HashFunction
fields.description: The cryptographic hash function used to compute the value given in the Hash Value.

fields.name: hashValue
fields.title: HashValue
fields.description: The value computed by a hash function applied to the media that will be delivered at the access point.

fields.name: PixelXDimension
fields.title: PixelXDimension
fields.description: The width in pixels of the media specified by the access point.

fields.name: PixelYDimension
fields.title: PixelYDimension
fields.description: The height in pixels of the media specified by the access point.

fields.name: feedbackURL
fields.title: Feedback URL
fields.comments: A uniform resource locator (URL) that points to a webpage on which a form may be submitted to gather feedback about the record.

schema.name: identification
schema.title: Identification
schema.description: A taxonomic determination (i.e., the assignment of dwc:Taxa to dwc:Organisms).

fields.name: identificationID
fields.title: Identification ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Identification.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: basedOnOccurrenceID
fields.title: Based On Occurrence ID
fields.description: An identifier for a dwc:Occurrence based on which a dwc:Identification was made.
fields.comments: Recommended best practice is to use a globally unique identifier.

fields.name: basedOnMaterialEntityID
fields.title: Based On Material Entity ID
